Comment_Body: You could do a couple dishes a person at la Merenda for $50 a person easy
Onesto you can get a bottle of wine and two pasta dishes for under 80, under 100 with tip.
Haven’t been to the pop up, but onesto is very good. Would make a nice birthday dinner!
I was just there a few weeks ago and I’d say La Merenda is much better tapas.
I disagree, but I love La Merenda too.
I take all my out of towners to La Merenda in Walkers Point. It has a huge menu and large indoor and outdoor dining areas and the food is always incredible
Not super close to where you will be but Camino's in West allis has a bunch of pinball machines. Also, Reunion Restaurant on Greenfield has a huge game area.

I regularly take my toddler to Colectivo for breakfast or lunch, and Cafe Hollander (or any of the Lowlands restaurants) are also always good for kids. Neither of these is kid-centric in the way you’re talking about, but are still great for kids. 

For a fancier place - we gambled and took our two year old with us to Lupi & Iris last week when our childcare fell through last minute and I read that they have high chairs, though no kid’s menu. We figured one of us would leave with her if she couldn’t handle it but thankfully she was great. She had a pasta dish that we sold to her as mac n cheese, and the staff was very gracious about it (and we were working hard to keep her on her best behavior which I think they appreciated). We had a fantastic meal, though I wish we could have enjoyed ourselves more. But if your kids can handle it, that’s an option for more of a fine dining experience!

>  La Merenda

This one looks fantastic, thank you!
Make sure it’s West Allis Camino. Walkers Point does not have kids menu or coloring.
Harbor House. Patio is amazing
Aperitivo in the Pritzlaff Building 4-6 pm, food and drink specials
Birch
I second Birch
Birch

Birch, EsterEv, and Bacchus each offer tasting menus.  I have not been to EsterEv since they relocated, but the tasting menu experience was excellent at their original spot. Birch is also excellent. Either one would be great. Bacchus is also good, but not as good as these two, imo.
Birch!!
Maybe not at fancy as Sanford but Room Service in Bay View was way up there in terms of quality and presentation.
birch, ristorante bartolotta, bacchus.

Based on all the feedback, it seems like Birch is the spot to check out. I booked the chefs counter there. 

Thanks the feedback.
Also Morel

On open table it mentioned that EsterEv is closed due to water damage, and hopes to reopen in early October. 

Booked the chefs counter at Birch for the time being, but might keep an eye out for EsterEv to come back online.

Yeah, and what we need is more affordable housing. 


Its laughable to Me that people believe that trickle down housing is the answer. "Yeah, so in 2027, maybe a few people will move up from mid price apartments and into the Edison, and those vacancies will trickle down and there will be a few hundred more affordable units in the city. Or maybe it will just be slowly filled by well to do people moving to the city, and other housing will be unaffected. Good luck!"


What we need is affordable housing, anf lots of it. Lots and lots. Thousands of units. Because it isn't just a matter of not enough housing, its that too much of it is priced In a way that many people can't afford and if many others are living very precariously due to rent taking a large proportion of their paychecks and could easily be made homeless by a car accident, illness, or other financial impact. The couture, 333, and the plyscrapee aren't going to change that. 


Edit: I'm not saying dont build it. Sure, build it, I dont care, but it is essentially irrelevant to the actual housing demands in Milwaukee.

> with plans for a second, a 50-story skyscraper, “using as as much wood as possible.”

Now this is what I’m eagerly awaiting, to see what becomes of this proposed project. The city entered a year long exclusive negotiating period close to a year ago with developers behind The Edison, so I wonder how that’s going. It might be a pie in the sky proposal unfortunately.

Maybe it’s reasonable to be skeptical of the Department of City Development accepting a $700M proposal from a developer that has not delivered a project yet.

The article you linked even states how Bauman was previously vocal in his support of the Edison.
La Merenda is great!
Second la merenda

McKinley Marina Pier walk with a drink from the Roundhouse Beer Garden.

Kilbourn Reservoir Park, then walk down to Kadish Park and maybe stop for a drink at Lakefront or walk across the marsupial bridge to Eagle Park for their nachos.

Foundation before Centro Cafe dinner in their backyard then Bar Centro jazz or see what’s up at Mad Planet or Timbuktu.

North side bar crawl: Warren’s Lounge or Taste for dinner, then darts at Tomato Patch, ending at Club Manhattan for pool or Cherry’s Lounge.

Bay View night: Burnheart’s, Vanguard, Wiggle Room, Blackbird.

Bike to Hubbard and Estabrook beer gardens.  South Shore and Humboldt too.

Close Wolski’s. If you’re nice they’ll give you the sticker without having to close it.

Grant Park Beach

Zócalo Food Truck Park

Swingin’ Door

Bay View Bowl or Landmark Lanes

La Pina for a tequila flight

Walk the Milwaukee River trails between North Avenue and Hampton

Get the chicken sandwich at Thrive on King

Art Bar

Lincoln Warehouse breweries at 1st/Becher and maybe tacos at Jalisco.

Visit 5 Points Art Gallery

Brandy Old Fashioned at Jamo’s

Not a lot of brunch options in that area. Oak Barrel is good. Copper on King has very good food but I haven’t tried their brunch before. They would probably have an opening for you. Reservations are tough this close to graduation so you may need to be willing to compromise on location/vibe.

I been in Mediterranean cuisine they are great good portions and tasty food they doing we got combo plate and lamb chops with and red wine. They clean! 
I didn’t see any Mediterranean restaurants that clean before!

Cosmos Cafe’s decent if you’re going solo and just want some quiet. But they don’t have kebabs, and I’m pretty sure they don’t change the oil for the fries often — every time I eat them, I end up with a stomach ache that night. It also feels a bit cramped in there. I’ve been looking for somewhere more comfy, and a friend actually recommended Mediterranean Cuisine.

Lebnani house is good for a date. 

Mediterranean Cuisine - nice work lunch/casual dinner.
Rice And Roll Bistro (Thai, sushi) and Blue Star Cafe (African) offer some of the very best food I've tried in Milwaukee. Both are very different  and offer remarkable flavorful dishes
story hill BKC is phenom. also wolffies!
birch is beloved!

The Eleanor in Greendale 

La Finca

SzeChuan

Hen's Deli 

HoneyButter in Franklin

The Edison

O'Lydia's 

Cute Robot
If you’d like lunch to stretch into the happy hour, I’d hit the Knick on Juneau. We absolutely love their chicken sliders and pretty much everything else on the tasting menu they have.
la merenda
Tasting menu on a Monday might be a challenge. If you are okay with tapas/small plates, then La Merenda on the south side of Water/1st street would be a great option
The La Merenda menu looks so interesting. We have done Spanish tapas and I like the choices from around the world. Definitely a contender. Thank you. I would never have found it.

I cooked at morel for about 2 years. It's fantastic. Everything that can reasonably be made in house, is made in house. With the exception of the hanger steak, almost every morsel in of meat is butchered and processed in by the food who end up doubling as butchers. Highly recommend getting their charcuterie board, rabbit ragout(may be venison or lamb), short rib and round for the kitchen.

Morel. The waitstaff is the best of the three restaurants, and the cocktails are the best of the three restaurants. All three have great food. All three have good atmospheres. You can’t go wrong with any of them, but Morel gets the nod for me. When taking out of town family, I want someone who is willing to dive deep to discuss the menu and drink options and in my experience I get more of that at Morel than the other two places.
Morel

All great (I’ve been to all of these at least 4 times each)

If I were showing off the city Morel is my pick of the three. But you really can’t go wrong at all.
Another vote for Morel! They have incredible food, drinks and service, every time. Be sure to make a reservation though! If it’s nice they might have the patio open too, which is an absolute vibe!
Of those three, Morel, hands down.

All three have rave reviews. I prefer Goodkind; had a couple of the best meals ever there. Odd Duck is very good but I’ve gotten a couple of disappointing small plates. Morel’s cuisine tends to be quite heavy, so if you have people in your party who don’t eat red meat, it can be a challenge. But I don’t think you can go wrong with any of these choices.

Goodkind and Odd Duck are two of my favorites in the city. It kind of depends on your mood. Odd Duck is mostly small plates for sharing while Goodkind is more traditional entrees. Haven’t been to Morel in ages.
Skip all three go to La Merenda, small plates, 1000 times better than odd duck, if I had to chose from the three I would do good kind.
Blue Star Cafe on Farwell for unique and truly amazing tasting Somalian food.  It's a no frills place and surprisingly inexpensive. Nice folks too!
sze chuan for Asian. double b's bbq. swingin door. story hill bkc for brunch. arby's on miller park way.
Three brothers (cash only), cafe India (bay view), La Merenda (little bit of everything), Carnevor for steaks (if your company is buying) roomservice (bayview if you can get a reservation)
If you want steak, Carnivore. If you don’t want steak, Morel.
I don’t think you can go wrong - I personally prefer morel. It’s more laid back and I prefer their menu options. But I have had excellent meals at both.

Carnevor, imo, is overrated. I suggest Milwaukee steakhouse. 

Whoever said go to la merenda is 100% correct. It will be a feast for all and it never disappoints.
Morel 100%. One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Their steak is better than Carnevor’s anyway. Been there twice, and each time we had bad service and room temp steak.
Morel no question

Really depends on what you want. Morel has great food and a nice atmosphere, but definitely not a steakhouse. Can guarantee you will have an excellent meal at Morel. If you want steak, and these are the two places you're choosing between, then Carnivore. However, if you want one of the best steaks in the city and a unique experience, I would recommend Five O'clock.
Do yourself a favor and go to three brothers or la merenda . Its your birthday after all.

If you’re looking for steak, I would suggest Carnevor over Morel.  But if you really want the best Milwaukee has to offer I’d suggest 5 o’clock steakhouse or Milwaukee steakhouse.  Completely different vibes compared to Carnevor, but they both do steak really well, and are much more affordable.  You’ll get more bang for your buck at both of those restaurants compared to going to Carnevor.

Hmm is morels steak just something they aren't known for? What's their speciality?
Morel isn’t a steak joint at all. It’s new American. Like beef short ribs, lamb, interesting fish.
Jealous! I’ve only ever found false morels. Enjoy!

The Colectivo on the lakefront is in the old water pumping station.

Foundation in Riverwest is an incredible Tiki bar if you're into those.

If you have nights with no dinner plans check out Birch.

Lakefront Brewery has a great tour.

The Villa Terrace is a cool old mansion, not a lot of permanent art but the house is beautiful, and it has a fantastic view of the lake.

I have to recommend Discourse - specifically the Radio Milwaukee building - for amazing coffee. The drinks are all delicious and very creative, plus the building is a great space. 

Also, while the weather is still nice I suggest that you help yourselves to one of the city’s many biergartens. I personally like the one in Juneau Park.

If you would like to spend some time outside, checking out Lake Park, Veterans Memorial Park or the marina are all great places to walk and see the lake.

Would also just like to say that Morel is an excellent choice for dinner, that is one of my favorite restaurants here. 

Hope you have a fun trip!

Milwaukee Art Museum on the lake is a good choice! I highly recommend David Barnett Art Gallery, it's my favorite spot in Milwaukee. It's free, just check the times. 

I personally think Colectivo has jumped the shark in recent years. Stone Creek Coffee is better. There's also a cute and quirky Fairgrounds Coffee somewhat near the Art Museum, but you have Fairgrounds in Chicago too. 

Highly recommend going to the Milwaukee Public Market just to walk through it. If you weren't already going to Saffron/Morel then you should get a panini or burger from Folz Family Restaurant in the MKE Public Market. 

Have fun!

Get the 7-course Surprise Tasting Menu at Sanford, At Random for drinks, brunch at Wolfie’s and walk around Sanger Garden’s Brewer’s Hill while you wait, Three Brothers another night, there are gorgeous trails by the river you shouldn’t miss — walk or bike the Oak Leaf trail to Estabrook Park beer garden in Shorewood, check out the south shore farmer’s market and walk around Bayview!

Thank you r/milwaukee !

We had a great long weekend in your fair city, thanks in part to all the suggestions and discussion you offered here. Of course it was impossible to try everything. This was our first trip to MKE but we'll be back.

Saint Kate was a great hotel - with a ProofPizza counter that came handy for a snack. Great pizza. Next time we'll explore something closer to a lively neighborhood -- perhaps an AirBnB -- but for a starting point Saint Kate was excellent and within walking distance from our key points this trip.

MAM is a great museum -- we took a detour on the way there to check the street fair by the Public Market. And got a little bit distracted by the festivities at the Italian Community Center, but we finally made it to the museum. Today we even watched its wings opening up. As much as I love Chicago's sprawling museums, I prefer smaller ones that can be viewed in 3 hours or less. MAM right on the edge there. Best ever? Kohler museum in Sheboygan -- the art place, not the product exhibit next to the factory.

Discourse was an amazing coffee shop. I tried their Channel Orange and Moonwater -- outstanding drinks. And while I was waiting for them I tried a plain espresso just to gauge the basic stuff. Most excellent. MSOE people are so fortunate.

Dinning wise, we loved both our choices: Morel and Saffron. Having dinned at Morel, can I now legitimately claim that I had a meal near with Jeffrey Dahmer had his? Or would that be too insensitive? 

The food at Morel was great and the service very friendly. Same for Saffron. We took the river walk to/from both restaurants and it was a marvelous experience.

Maybe I was a bit optimistic with our schedule but we did not have time for microbreweries and bookstores. Next time. But I can tell you that the bar at the ground floor at Saint Kate makes a mean gin martini.

For years, we've been driving through MKE on our way to our property up on Washington Island. I am glad this time we decided to stop for a couple of nights. We'll be back definitely. 

Thanks for the tips everyone.

Leo -- OP.

I cooked at morel for 2 years. I highly recommend it! Every cut of meat in the restaurant has been hand butchered. The only exception is the hanger steak because it's just a little ridiculous to cut up a cow in a tiny walkers point kitchen. 

If the rabbit ragout is on the menu definitely give it a try! That and the lamb carpaccio. Can't miss! And don't forget about Caroline's just down the block if youre into jazz and cocktails. 

MAM is a wonderful museum, highly recommend going there and walking around the lakefront afterwards.
Can't go wrong at Sanford's imo! Enjoy.
Birch is one of my absolute favs so I echo that plus everything else

If you booked at Morel (skip the ham biscuit and go with the mushroom fricassee) grab a beer at Indeed. Good beer and wide range of styles. They also have a great roof top space across the street. Check out one of the county beer gardens, South Shore Terrace, Veteran’s Park and Juneau Park have great city and lake views.

Harbor House has happy hour from 4 to 6 if you want drinks an appetizer and nice views of the lake, then you could have dinner there or go elsewhere - [https://www.bartolottas.com/harbor-house/specials/happy-hour](https://www.bartolottas.com/harbor-house/specials/happy-hour)

Milwaukee Sail Loft isn't fancy, but if the weather is nice you can eat on the patio, then stroll the riverwalk to Purple Door ice cream for dessert.
I would hardly call Stella Van Buren fine dining…
Note sure Sanford vs AJ Bombers were the best examples...

is reddit anti new apartments?

the fitz is a decent price point for new construction, its a good building in a good area.

A 1 bed at the Fitz is something like $2200 a month which is more than double the housing budget of a lot of people in this city. I think the pushback is more from people who want AFFORDABLE housing, and less from the aforementioned NIMBYs

Just looked and it’s 1750. That’s market value for a new unit with gym, washer dryer, and brand new appliances. Also looks like they have underground parking for pay. Obviously not cheap but less than what was mentioned and there is a market for it. Now compare that to a building like 333 water in an area of town without a walkable grocery store and lack of outdoor space. I think the fitz is a better deal.

its not totally regardless. I think we are seeing the demand for true high end apartments, such as coture, is dried up so more of those wont help our housing market. But something like the fitz or the new downer building going up are good. things that are nice but not luxury

Good for Alderman Westmoreland for calling out the community. Unfortunately, the dirtbags strewing trash are not the types to read or watch news, and they do not appreciate having their poor behavior challenged personally.
I keep hearing about Westmoreland, and everything I hear about him, I like quite a bit. Good on him, glad he’s trying to keep this city the best it can be.
I drove past police station on Lisbon....tons of trash on their grounds.  Thought "what would Westmoreland say?"

dude… i can be vehemently against littering *without* being an asshole about it. some people improve with a healthy dose of public shaming, but the vast majority do not. you and westmoreland have more than enough reason to be enraged about the state of your streets, litter is disgusting and unsightly and a symptom of a city that does not care about its image—obviously. no one is pro-littering or saying that people should litter or even implying that litter is okay. i am just pointing out that i think there are better approaches than this, ones that don’t use targeted language. whether or not that is true is irrelevant, because it is just the opinion of one single person living in our city. i’m not out there passing legislation or having say over peoples’ individual actions, i am just someone who is also tired of seeing litter, but who has seen before that passive aggression is largely ineffective in creating change even if it is cathartic. we both want the same thing, even if we disagree on how we get there. again: i am not your enemy.

you raise a fantastic point. upon further consideration, i never actually disagreed with westmoreland’s messaging at all, i am just uncomfortable with the somewhat racially charged tone of it—but it would be disingenuous of me to pretend that that isn’t a part of the issue, especially when coming from their black alderman. but, that is the area that *he* is representing, and he obviously would know it much better than i. from where i stand, i see litter as more of a symptom of the deeper problem that makes milwaukee such a segregated city, and so im more inclined to want to look at the root cause rather than the details that come as a result of it. i think that black communities need more direct support, less shame, especially about something that’s being treated as a cosmetic issue (let alone the environmental consequences). that’s where my sentiment initially came from. i’m typically very pro-aggressive-action, but i guess it feels a bit different when directed towards my own city. tough love and whatnot. the hostile tone of their initial response didn’t help, though.

you are right though, that if i care, i’ll do more than just advocate for less anger on the internet. i already spend some days de-trashing parts of my neighborhood, but if i actually give a shit i will do more than just that. i do genuinely hope that alderman westmoreland’s message leads to some change of behavior.

You are reading something that wasn't written.

Alder Westmoreland clearly sees himself as a leader of the people of his neighborhood, many of whom look like him. Those people are (a) fulfilling every stereotype that people outside the city have of them, (b) screwing up the space where he lives, and (c) making him, personally, look like a clown. It would be more embarrassing if he weren't angry. 

If you are not a litterer, then this letter is not talking to you no matter what color you are. In fact, if you are a Black person in this city, you should be mad at the litterers, not him. They are making you look bad too. 

I understand the urge to be kind, but there comes a time you have to stop wasting time feeling bad for people who flat out DGAF, even if they are struggling. Being in poverty is not directly a sign of general virtue. People in poverty can just suck at humanity, same as anyone else.
What are areas that one would look to find Morels. Growing in specific dead trees correct?

These look like real morels, but people need to make sure they don't go picking false morels. Besides being toxic, they may be linked to ALS.   
[https://www.thegreatmorel.com/false-morels/](https://www.thegreatmorel.com/false-morels/)
Morel less ..
Morel sautéed in steak pan drippings, then used to make a mushroom cream sauce to go on the steak - morel and chanterelle seasons are about the only time I cook steak, just for this reason.
Eat after cooking, don’t DIY without learning how to distinguish from false morels first (half-frees are fine).

Hardly anybody gives up their secret morel hunting grounds. 

That said, at my old house they used to come up in the shadow of the neighbor's dead elm tree. They grow on the ground, not on the tree itself
Fortunately morels are one of the easiest choice edibles to ID and distinguish from toxic lookalikes.

Allegiant flies from Sanford to Appleton. Appleton is the midwest hub of Allegiant and their website lists several other cities in Florida they travel to. Rapids has a new Enterprise rental location (715-956-9876). The airfare is super cheap, and you could rent a car for the day and then drop it off in Rapids once you get here.
To save money, call the Enterprise location directly to make reservations where you are flying from. Everytime I fly from Appleton to Sanford, I always have to pay extra for my rental car because I booked through Allegiant.
Good luck:)
